latestVersion.versionNote:
This spreadsheet provides calculations for the second generation Public:Private Framework.			
The initial version was posted on my web site in 2006. http://www.general.uwa.edu.au/u/dpannell/dp0601.htm			
This version was published in Land Economics, May 2008. 			
It includes changes 1 to 6 listed below (i.e. changes relative to the original web version).			
			
	Date	Changes compared to the first generation version.	
	1/23/08	1	Include private net benefits (net of learning costs) in benefits component of the BCR for extension.
		2	Include private net benefits (not net of learning costs*) in benefits component of the BCR for positive incentives.
			*because they are assumed to be paid for by the environmental manager.
		3	Include private benefits (avoidance of learning costs**) in benefits components of the BCR for negative incentives.
			**the cost of losing private benefits was already included, so there was a bit of inconsistency in the treatment of
			private benefits relative to th

fields.value: Replication data for: Public Benefits, Private Benefits, and Policy Mechanism Choice for Land-Use Change for Environmental Benefits

dsDescriptionValue.value: The choice of policy mechanisms for encouraging environmentally beneficial land-use change should depend on the relative levels of private (or internal) net benefits, and public (or external) net benefits. A map of recommended policy mechanisms is developed, depending on the relative levels of these variables. Positive incentives, negative incentives, and extension need to be targeted carefully to appropriate projectsâ€”where private net benefits are closer to zero, and/or public net benefits are more extremely positive or negative. Technology development is suggested where private net costs outweigh public net benefits. No action is recommended for many potential projects.

publicationCitation.value: Pannell, D.J. (2008). Public benefits, private benefits, and policy intervention for land-use change for environmental benefits, Land Economics, 84(2): 225-240; doi:10.3368/le.84.2.225
